Author: kpro1982
Content: I find this issue challenging. I think your approach to the problem is too theoretical.  In most cases, if you care at all, you want to __require__  code to run on a particular machine. This is done with a `if(GetGame().IsDedicated())` check in your code or an `#ifdef` block.  If you are curious where code is running you can find that out easily using WB.  WB will not hit breakpoints in code that runs on the server if it is in "debug client" mode and visa versa. The same is true for Print().  If you put a print inside an  `if(GetGame().IsDedicated())` block, that Print will only show up in the WB console if you are debuging in server and visa versa. If you want to know why code is running on one machine or the other, you can stack trace it back.  It will always be the case that code that runs on the server was called from the server and visa versa -- because you know they are different machines often in different locations. RPCs are the exception (and I think the only exception?) where you can call code on the other machine.  But the vanilla game has its own internal mechanism for keeping synch between server and clients. I think most of the time, we piggy back off of  that. If you want to force code to run on a specific machine e.g. the server.  Then you call it on that machine by hooking into a class like `MissionServer` that runs on server only. Or if you want to ensure that it runs on the client you can call it from `MissionGameplay` that runs only on the client. If you want the code to run on both, you can call in from `MissionBase` which runs on both. I recently found this documentation for CF which identifies a bunch of classes and states where they run.  <https://github.com/Arkensor/DayZ-CommunityFramework/blob/production/docs/Modules/index.md> CF is amazing and all its contributors are F*ing heroes! As I said, I still find this issue very challenging. If I've mistated anything, I hope those here that know better will correct me so that I'll learn something new. üôÇ
